description: Toddlers explore fabric scraps of different textures, colors, and sizes.
parent_instruction: Place a variety of fabric scraps in a basket. Slowly pull out one piece and rub it between your fingers, then offer it to your toddler. Let them explore pulling, rubbing, and wrapping the pieces. Watch what interests them most and follow their lead.
variations: Sort fabrics into soft, rough, or smooth piles.
Play a simple game of hiding a small toy under one scrap.
Use a scarf or long strip for gentle peek-a-boo play.

materials: jar or container with wide opening
description: Toddlers drop buttons into a jar, enjoying the sound and practicing finger control.
parent_instruction: Place the jar and a small pile of buttons in front of your toddler. Slowly pick up one button and drop it into the jar so they can watch and hear the sound. Slide the buttons toward your toddler and let them explore dropping them in. Stay close in case a button needs to be removed quickly.
variations: Sort buttons by color before dropping them into the jar.
Count each button as it goes into the jar.
Use a container with a smaller opening for added challenge, with close supervision.

description: Toddlers press stampers or toys into play dough to create shapes and textures.
parent_instruction: Flatten a ball of play dough on a tray. Press one stamper or toy into the dough and lift it to show the imprint. Offer a stamper to your toddler and watch as they press and lift. Let them repeat with different tools and shapes.
variations: Use natural objects like leaves or shells to make new textures.
Invite your toddler to line up their stamped shapes in a row.
Offer two colors of dough and let them mix and stamp together.

description: Toddlers stack blocks into towers and knock them down, exploring balance and cause-and-effect.
parent_instruction: Place a few blocks on the floor and slowly build a small tower. Pause and let your toddler watch as you gently knock it over. Offer the blocks and observe as they stack and topple in their own way. Allow repeated knocking as part of the learning.
variations: Sort blocks by color or size before building.
Build towers on different surfaces like carpet and hard floor.
Invite your toddler to build a tower taller than your hand or a favorite toy.

description: Toddlers stack blocks into towers and knock them down, exploring balance and cause-and-effect.
parent_instruction: Place a few blocks on the floor and slowly build a small tower. Pause and let your toddler watch as you gently knock it over. Offer the blocks and observe as they stack and topple in their own way. Allow repeated knocking as part of the learning.
variations: Sort blocks by color or size before building.
Build towers on different surfaces like carpet and hard floor.
Invite your toddler to build a tower taller than your hand or a favorite toy.

description: Toddlers explore fabric scraps of different textures, colors, and sizes.
parent_instruction: Place a variety of fabric scraps in a basket. Slowly pull out one piece and rub it between your fingers, then offer it to your toddler. Let them explore pulling, rubbing, and wrapping the pieces. Watch what interests them most and follow their lead.
variations: Sort fabrics into soft, rough, or smooth piles.
Play a simple game of hiding a small toy under one scrap.
Use a scarf or long strip for gentle peek-a-boo play.

description: Toddlers press stampers or toys into play dough to create shapes and textures.
parent_instruction: Flatten a ball of play dough on a tray. Press one stamper or toy into the dough and lift it to show the imprint. Offer a stamper to your toddler and watch as they press and lift. Let them repeat with different tools and shapes.
variations: Use natural objects like leaves or shells to make new textures.
Invite your toddler to line up their stamped shapes in a row.
Offer two colors of dough and let them mix and stamp together.

description: Toddlers reveal leaf shapes by rubbing crayons over paper placed on top of leaves.
parent_instruction: Place a leaf on the table and cover it with a piece of paper. Gently rub a crayon sideways over the leaf area until the shape appears. Offer a crayon to your toddler and let them explore rubbing different spots. Name what you see only if they seem interested in talking.
variations: Collect leaves of different shapes and compare the rubbings.
Create a small book of leaf rubbings stapled together.
Try rubbings with other textured objects like coins or fabric.

description: Toddlers roll cars down a ramp, exploring speed, slope, and simple physics.
parent_instruction: Prop a piece of cardboard on a stack of books to make a gentle ramp. Slowly roll one car down the ramp so your toddler can see what happens. Offer a car and observe as they roll it repeatedly. Stay nearby to adjust the ramp and keep the play safe.
variations: Change the height of the ramp to compare slow and fast rolls.
Race two cars side by side and see which car moves faster.
Add a simple tunnel made from another piece of cardboard.

description: Toddlers reveal leaf shapes by rubbing crayons over paper placed on top of leaves.
parent_instruction: Place a leaf on the table and cover it with a piece of paper. Gently rub a crayon sideways over the leaf area until the shape appears. Offer a crayon to your toddler and let them explore rubbing different spots. Name what you see only if they seem interested in talking.
variations: Collect leaves of different shapes and compare the rubbings.
Create a small book of leaf rubbings stapled together.
Try rubbings with other textured objects like coins or fabric.

description: Toddlers draw lines, loops, and shapes freely, building early writing skills.
parent_instruction: Tape the paper to the table so it won’t slide. Slowly draw a simple line or loop with a crayon, then set the crayon down. Offer a crayon to your toddler and let them draw in their own way. Watch quietly, commenting lightly on colors only if they welcome it.
variations: Draw gentle paths or shapes for your toddler to trace over.
Offer only two or three colors at a time to simplify choices.
Tape paper to a wall or easel for vertical drawing.

description: Toddlers use tongs to move cotton balls between bowls, strengthening hand muscles and coordination.
parent_instruction: Place cotton balls in one bowl and the tongs beside it. Slowly pick up one cotton ball with the tongs and move it to the empty bowl. Hand the tongs to your toddler and allow them to try, staying quiet as they practice. Offer gentle help only if they seem frustrated.
variations: Use two colors of cotton balls and invite color sorting.
Switch to smaller bowls to make placement more precise.
Count each cotton ball as it moves from one bowl to another.

description: Toddlers walk, jump, or drive toy cars along taped lines on the floor.
parent_instruction: Place a few simple tape lines on the floor. Slowly walk heel-to-toe along one line to show how to follow it. Invite your toddler to walk, tiptoe, or drive a toy along the path. Stay close to support balance if needed.
variations: Create zigzag or curved paths for added fun.
Turn one line into a simple ‘balance beam’ challenge.
Add arrows and talk about directions like forward and backward.

description: Toddlers place stickers along lines, building finger strength and focus.
parent_instruction: Draw a few simple lines or shapes on the paper. Peel one sticker and place it carefully along a line. Hand the sticker sheet to your toddler and let them choose where to place the rest. Watch quietly, stepping in only if they ask for help peeling.
variations: Draw zigzag or wavy lines for added challenge.
Use shape or picture stickers and talk about what they show.
Invite your toddler to create a sticker path from one side of the page to the other.

description: Toddlers stack blocks into towers and knock them down, exploring balance and cause-and-effect.
parent_instruction: Place a few blocks on the floor and slowly build a small tower. Pause and let your toddler watch as you gently knock it over. Offer the blocks and observe as they stack and topple in their own way. Allow repeated knocking as part of the learning.
variations: Sort blocks by color or size before building.
Build towers on different surfaces like carpet and hard floor.
Invite your toddler to build a tower taller than your hand or a favorite toy.

description: Toddlers explore magnets by moving small items on a tray and feeling the pull.
parent_instruction: Place a few magnetic items on the tray and hold the magnet wand above one piece. Slowly move the wand until the item sticks, then lift it. Offer the wand to your toddler and watch as they try. Stay nearby to ensure small items are used safely.
variations: Hide some magnetic items under paper and see which spots lift.
Mix in non-magnetic items and see which ones do not stick.
Sort items into ‘sticks’ and ‘does not stick’ groups together.

description: Toddlers practice tossing soft balls into a basket, building coordination.
parent_instruction: Place the basket a short distance away and drop one ball gently into it. Hand a ball to your toddler and let them try tossing. Step back and observe, moving the basket closer or farther if needed. Keep the mood light and playful.
variations: Change the distance to make tossing easier or harder.
Use different types of soft balls and compare how they feel.
Invite your toddler to collect all the balls and start again.

variations: Collect leaves of different shapes and compare the rubbings.
Create a small book of leaf rubbings stapled together.
Try rubbings with other textured objects like coins or fabric.

variations: Change the height of the ramp to compare slow and fast rolls.
Race two cars side by side and see which car moves faster.
Add a simple tunnel made from another piece of cardboard.

variations: Sort blocks by color or size before building.
Build towers on different surfaces like carpet and hard floor.
Invite your toddler to build a tower taller than your hand or a favorite toy.

description: Toddlers pour water between cups, practicing control and everyday life skills.
parent_instruction: Place the cups and pitcher on a tray and pour a small amount of water into the pitcher. Slowly pour water from the pitcher into one cup, then back again. Offer the pitcher to your toddler and stay close while they pour. Use the towel together to wipe any spills when they are finished.
variations: Use cups of different shapes or sizes and compare how they fill.
Add a funnel between the pitcher and cup for extra interest.
Tint the water with a drop of food coloring for visual appeal.

Create a small book of leaf rubbings stapled together.
Try rubbings with other textured objects like coins or fabric.

materials: jar or container with wide opening
description: Toddlers drop buttons into a jar, enjoying the sound and practicing finger control.
parent_instruction: Place the jar and a small pile of buttons in front of your toddler. Slowly pick up one button and drop it into the jar so they can watch and hear the sound. Slide the buttons toward your toddler and let them explore dropping them in. Stay close in case a button needs to be removed quickly.
variations: Sort buttons by color before dropping them into the jar.
Count each button as it goes into the jar.
Use a container with a smaller opening for added challenge, with close supervision.

description: Toddlers pour water between cups, practicing control and everyday life skills.
parent_instruction: Place the cups and pitcher on a tray and pour a small amount of water into the pitcher. Slowly pour water from the pitcher into one cup, then back again. Offer the pitcher to your toddler and stay close while they pour. Use the towel together to wipe any spills when they are finished.
variations: Use cups of different shapes or sizes and compare how they fill.
Add a funnel between the pitcher and cup for extra interest.
Tint the water with a drop of food coloring for visual appeal.

description: Toddlers walk, jump, or drive toy cars along taped lines on the floor.
parent_instruction: Place a few simple tape lines on the floor. Slowly walk heel-to-toe along one line to show how to follow it. Invite your toddler to walk, tiptoe, or drive a toy along the path. Stay close to support balance if needed.
variations: Create zigzag or curved paths for added fun.
Turn one line into a simple ‘balance beam’ challenge.
Add arrows and talk about directions like forward and backward.

description: Toddlers drop buttons into a jar, enjoying the sound and practicing finger control.

parent_instruction: Draw a few simple lines or shapes on the paper. Peel one sticker and place it carefully along a line. Hand the sticker sheet to your toddler and let them choose where to place the rest. Watch quietly, stepping in only if they ask for help peeling.
variations: Draw zigzag or wavy lines for added challenge.
Use shape or picture stickers and talk about what they show.
Invite your toddler to create a sticker path from one side of the page to the other.

description: Toddlers reveal leaf shapes by rubbing crayons over paper placed on top of leaves.

variations: Collect leaves of different shapes and compare the rubbings.

description: Toddlers scoop floating foam shapes from water and sort them by color or shape.
parent_instruction: Place the foam shapes in a shallow bin of water. Slowly scoop one shape with the spoon and place it on the side. Offer the spoon to your toddler and let them scoop at their own pace. Stay nearby to keep water play safe.
variations: Sort shapes by color onto different towels or cloths.
Name each shape as it is scooped out of the water.
Use only one shape at a time to keep the task simple.

description: Toddlers press stampers or toys into play dough to create shapes and textures.
parent_instruction: Flatten a ball of play dough on a tray. Press one stamper or toy into the dough and lift it to show the imprint. Offer a stamper to your toddler and watch as they press and lift. Let them repeat with different tools and shapes.
variations: Use natural objects like leaves or shells to make new textures.
Invite your toddler to line up their stamped shapes in a row.
Offer two colors of dough and let them mix and stamp together.

description: Toddlers scoop and pour pom-poms between cups, exploring texture and simple cause-and-effect.
parent_instruction: Set out the cups and a small pile of pom-poms on a tray. Slowly scoop a few pom-poms into one cup, then pour them into another. Offer the scoop to your toddler and step back, watching how they choose to move the pom-poms. Stay nearby to keep the play safe and calm.
variations: Offer cups of different sizes and see which holds more pom-poms.
Introduce color sorting by giving each color its own cup.

variations: Draw gentle paths or shapes for your toddler to trace over.
Offer only two or three colors at a time to simplify choices.
Tape paper to a wall or easel for vertical drawing.

description: Toddlers pour water between cups, practicing control and everyday life skills.
parent_instruction: Place the cups and pitcher on a tray and pour a small amount of water into the pitcher. Slowly pour water from the pitcher into one cup, then back again. Offer the pitcher to your toddler and stay close while they pour. Use the towel together to wipe any spills when they are finished.
variations: Use cups of different shapes or sizes and compare how they fill.
Add a funnel between the pitcher and cup for extra interest.
Tint the water with a drop of food coloring for visual appeal.

description: Toddlers explore fabric scraps of different textures, colors, and sizes.
parent_instruction: Place a variety of fabric scraps in a basket. Slowly pull out one piece and rub it between your fingers, then offer it to your toddler. Let them explore pulling, rubbing, and wrapping the pieces. Watch what interests them most and follow their lead.
variations: Sort fabrics into soft, rough, or smooth piles.
Play a simple game of hiding a small toy under one scrap.
Use a scarf or long strip for gentle peek-a-boo play.

description: Toddlers scoop floating foam shapes from water and sort them by color or shape.
parent_instruction: Place the foam shapes in a shallow bin of water. Slowly scoop one shape with the spoon and place it on the side. Offer the spoon to your toddler and let them scoop at their own pace. Stay nearby to keep water play safe.
variations: Sort shapes by color onto different towels or cloths.
Name each shape as it is scooped out of the water.
Use only one shape at a time to keep the task simple.

description: Toddlers roll cars down a ramp, exploring speed, slope, and simple physics.
parent_instruction: Prop a piece of cardboard on a stack of books to make a gentle ramp. Slowly roll one car down the ramp so your toddler can see what happens. Offer a car and observe as they roll it repeatedly. Stay nearby to adjust the ramp and keep the play safe.
variations: Change the height of the ramp to compare slow and fast rolls.
Race two cars side by side and see which car moves faster.
Add a simple tunnel made from another piece of cardboard.

description: Toddlers place stickers along lines, building finger strength and focus.
parent_instruction: Draw a few simple lines or shapes on the paper. Peel one sticker and place it carefully along a line. Hand the sticker sheet to your toddler and let them choose where to place the rest. Watch quietly, stepping in only if they ask for help peeling.
variations: Draw zigzag or wavy lines for added challenge.
Use shape or picture stickers and talk about what they show.
Invite your toddler to create a sticker path from one side of the page to the other.

description: Toddlers explore magnets by moving small items on a tray and feeling the pull.
parent_instruction: Place a few magnetic items on the tray and hold the magnet wand above one piece. Slowly move the wand until the item sticks, then lift it. Offer the wand to your toddler and watch as they try. Stay nearby to ensure small items are used safely.
variations: Hide some magnetic items under paper and see which spots lift.
Mix in non-magnetic items and see which ones do not stick.
Sort items into ‘sticks’ and ‘does not stick’ groups together.

description: Toddlers roll cars down a ramp, exploring speed, slope, and simple physics.
parent_instruction: Prop a piece of cardboard on a stack of books to make a gentle ramp. Slowly roll one car down the ramp so your toddler can see what happens. Offer a car and observe as they roll it repeatedly. Stay nearby to adjust the ramp and keep the play safe.
variations: Change the height of the ramp to compare slow and fast rolls.
Race two cars side by side and see which car moves faster.
Add a simple tunnel made from another piece of cardboard.

description: Toddlers stack blocks into towers and knock them down, exploring balance and cause-and-effect.
parent_instruction: Place a few blocks on the floor and slowly build a small tower. Pause and let your toddler watch as you gently knock it over. Offer the blocks and observe as they stack and topple in their own way. Allow repeated knocking as part of the learning.
variations: Sort blocks by color or size before building.
Build towers on different surfaces like carpet and hard floor.
Invite your toddler to build a tower taller than your hand or a favorite toy.

description: Toddlers draw lines, loops, and shapes freely, building early writing skills.
parent_instruction: Tape the paper to the table so it won’t slide. Slowly draw a simple line or loop with a crayon, then set the crayon down. Offer a crayon to your toddler and let them draw in their own way. Watch quietly, commenting lightly on colors only if they welcome it.
variations: Draw gentle paths or shapes for your toddler to trace over.
Offer only two or three colors at a time to simplify choices.
Tape paper to a wall or easel for vertical drawing.

description: Toddlers explore magnets by moving small items on a tray and feeling the pull.
parent_instruction: Place a few magnetic items on the tray and hold the magnet wand above one piece. Slowly move the wand until the item sticks, then lift it. Offer the wand to your toddler and watch as they try. Stay nearby to ensure small items are used safely.
variations: Hide some magnetic items under paper and see which spots lift.
Mix in non-magnetic items and see which ones do not stick.
Sort items into ‘sticks’ and ‘does not stick’ groups together.

description: Toddlers walk, jump, or drive toy cars along taped lines on the floor.
parent_instruction: Place a few simple tape lines on the floor. Slowly walk heel-to-toe along one line to show how to follow it. Invite your toddler to walk, tiptoe, or drive a toy along the path. Stay close to support balance if needed.
variations: Create zigzag or curved paths for added fun.
Turn one line into a simple ‘balance beam’ challenge.
Add arrows and talk about directions like forward and backward.

description: Toddlers press stampers or toys into play dough to create shapes and textures.
parent_instruction: Flatten a ball of play dough on a tray. Press one stamper or toy into the dough and lift it to show the imprint. Offer a stamper to your toddler and watch as they press and lift. Let them repeat with different tools and shapes.
variations: Use natural objects like leaves or shells to make new textures.
Invite your toddler to line up their stamped shapes in a row.
Offer two colors of dough and let them mix and stamp together.

materials: jar or container with wide opening
description: Toddlers drop buttons into a jar, enjoying the sound and practicing finger control.
parent_instruction: Place the jar and a small pile of buttons in front of your toddler. Slowly pick up one button and drop it into the jar so they can watch and hear the sound. Slide the buttons toward your toddler and let them explore dropping them in. Stay close in case a button needs to be removed quickly.
variations: Sort buttons by color before dropping them into the jar.
Count each button as it goes into the jar.
Use a container with a smaller opening for added challenge, with close supervision.

variations: Hide some magnetic items under paper and see which spots lift.

description: Toddlers practice tossing soft balls into a basket, building coordination.
parent_instruction: Place the basket a short distance away and drop one ball gently into it. Hand a ball to your toddler and let them try tossing. Step back and observe, moving the basket closer or farther if needed. Keep the mood light and playful.
variations: Change the distance to make tossing easier or harder.
Use different types of soft balls and compare how they feel.
Invite your toddler to collect all the balls and start again.
